awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research:  Development of a thermodynamic sea ice model with resolved melt ponds for use in linking climate model parameterizations with field data

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
As the sun rises higher in the Arctic sky and conditions begin to warm in late spring, snow on the surface of the ice begins to melt. The resulting meltwater pools in low points on the surface of the ice, dramatically enhancing the amount of sunlight absorbed by the ice, and leading to further melting. Better understanding how these ponds form and the role they play in sea ice loss important for predicting future sea ice conditions and future climate.

The purpose of this project was to process a host of melting sea ice observations, especially those taken with a terrestrial LiDAR scanner, to create a dataset for initialization and validation of a thermodynamic sea ice model with resolved melt ponds. A LiDAR scanner is a unique that enables very high accuracy (1cm) maps of the ice surface to be created, over an area of a couple football fields. Methods were developed in this work to further process LiDAR scan data into surface topography models. A workflow was established that allowed the scans to be corrected for atmospheric refraction of the laser, co-registered using reflectors captured within the scans, cleaned of erroneous points and reflections, and exported as 3D surfaces for use in model initialization and validation. A miss-applied calibration in the scanner’s internal settings was discovered during the processing and a correction was created for the data. Along with the LiDAR data, other observations collected at the same sites, including melt pond and snow depths, surface albedos, ice thicknesses, aerial photographs, and surface characterizations, were processed and posted. The datasets are now publicly available at www.chrispolashenski.com/data, and have been taken in by our collaborative partners at Oregon State University to use for calibrating their model of melt pond evolution on sea ice. The results of this model will help further improve the predictability of sea ice conditions in the Arctic – important for stakeholders ranging from wildlife management agencies to native subsistence hunters and shipping companies to oil and gas developers.


Last Modified: 08/22/2012
Modified by: Erland M Schulson
